Plate it up next to my squash

And let's give this a try.

And the beef tastes like,

as beef without seasoning

And the squash tastes like some
plain old mashed-up squash.

As is so often the case
with "It's Always Sunny",
I think we can do a whole lot better.

Let's start by sauteing
one roughly chopped onion

in a shallow Dutch oven
for about three minutes
or until lightly caramelized.
Grate in a small knob of ginger.
One clove of garlic.
Add one teaspoon fermented chili paste,
one tablespoon five spice powder,

preferably toasted,
hand ground, and sifted

because sometimes extra
fussy tastes extra good.
Saute those together
for about 30 seconds or until fragrant,

and then deglaze with one and
a half cups of dry red wine.

Scrape up all that good stuff
off the bottom of the pot.

Add one and a half cups
of homemade chicken stock.

Then we're adding two
tablespoons of brown sugar,

1/3 cup each soy sauce
and Worcestershire sauce.

Mix together and then bring
this guy up to a simmer.

Once bubbling, we're
finally adding our beef.
In this case, four nice, meaty, short ribs

that we've salted and let
rest at room temperature
for half an hour before adding.

Add enough water so that the
liquid comes most of the way
up the sides of the short ribs

and drop this guy into a
325 degree Fahrenheit oven
for two and a half to three hours,
flipping the short ribs halfway through.
Plenty of time to contend with our squash,

which we're gonna cut in
half and scoop out the seeds.
Score, if desired.
I don't know if this does anything,

but it feels like the
professional thing to do.

Then rub these guys down with
a little bit of vegetable oil,

some kosher salt, and some
freshly ground black pepper,

making sure to rub it
into all the crevices.
Then we're placing these guys cut down
on a preheated baking sheet.

This is gonna give us a headstart
on the maillard reaction

and help us earn some
extra browning points.

Into a preheated 400 degree
Fahrenheit oven it goes
for about half an hour before flipping,
returning to the oven,

and allowing to cook for
another 15, 20 minutes
until nicely browned

and the flesh shows no
resistance when stabbed.
Now, while this guy is still nice and hot,

we're gonna scoop it out
and turn it into a puree
by virtue of a food processor.
To the squash,

I'm going to add a little
splash of brown butter,
I've got two sticks worth here.
And a little splash of heavy cream
to help stabilize the emulsion.
Then with the food processor running,

I'm gonna slowly stream the
rest of the brown butter
in through the feed tube

so all we're left with is a
smooth, rich creamy emulsion
that's just about as much brown butter
as it is butternut squash.
So as you can imagine,

it is lick the spoon and
pound the table good.

Now all we need is beef and
sauce that are flavorful enough

that they can contend

ribs, fresh out the oven.
We're pulling the meat

and their accompanying
bones out of the sauce,

straining the sauce

And then we're gonna de-fat it.
Carefully skimming the fat off the top
and removing it into a small bowl.

Then we're gonna use the
sauce and its accompanying fat
to make a jus gras,

which is basically just
a fat four to five gravy.
Got about a cup and a half of the sauce

half teaspoon of xanthan gum

Then with the blender
running on medium speed,

I'm gonna slowly stream the
fat in through the feed tube
for the second time today.
